Railroad Western Maryland Railroad |season= |sights= |hazards=Severe Weather
}} trailhead, from top of access trail]] The 'Great Allegheny Passage' (GAP) is
a rail trail in Maryland and Pennsylvania. It is the central trail of a network
of long-distance hiker-biker trails covering hundreds of miles through the
Allegheny region of the Appalachian Mountains, connecting Washington, D.C. to
Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and beyond.

The multi-use trail, suitable for biking and walking, occupies abandoned
corridors of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, Pittsburgh and Lake Erie Railroad,
Union Railroad and the Western Maryland Railroad. When completed, the Great
Allegheny Passage will extend from Cumberland, Maryland to Point State Park in
downtown Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, with a branch (Montour Trail) to the
Pittsburgh International Airport.

This GAP also connects with the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal towpath trail, which
runs for an additional between Cumberland, Maryland and Washington, DC -
creating a continuous non-motorized corridor, long, from McKeesport, near
Pittsburgh (ultimately to begin from Pittsburgh's Point State Park ) to
Washington, DC. The Great Allegheny Passage is a segment of the Potomac Heritage
National Scenic Trail, one of eight nationally-designated scenic
trails. {{cite web |url=http://www.nps.gov/pohe |title=Potomac Heritage
National Scenic Trail |accessdate=2008-12-17 |author= |last= |first=
|authorlink= |coauthors= |date=2008-12-05 |publisher=National Park Service
|pages= |language= |doi= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |quote= }}
